facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 120 of 1955 is before the Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 120 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 25, 1949 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 55 of 1946

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 25, 1949, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 55 of 1946, arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 26, 1945,

facts.text: Madras High Court appeal arose from judgment dated November 26, 1945 of District Judge of Bellary in Original Suit No. 39 of 1943

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 26, 1945, of the Court of the District Judge of Bellary in Original Suit No. 39 of 1943. V. Viswanatha Sastri and K. R. Chaudhury for B. K. B. Naidu, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 19, 1958 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM, J.-This appeal is before us on a certificate granted by the High Court as according to that Court a substantial question of law arose in the case which was stated by it to be Is the adoption of the second defendant invalid,

facts.text: High Court granted certificate on substantial question of law regarding validity of adoption of second defendant due to lack of approval of five trustees in paragraph 14 of will of Kari Veerappa Exbt. P-2 a

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is before us on a certificate granted by the High Court as according to that Court a substantial question of law arose in the case which was stated by it to be Is the adoption of the second defendant invalid, as the approval or companysent of the five trustees mentioned in paragraph 14 of the will of Kari Veerappa, Exbt. P-2 a  was number obtained and is the authority to adopt at an end if any one of those five persons did number accept the trusteeship or died before the adoption or refused to give their approval .

facts.text: Kari Veerappa was the last male owner of the estate

anchor.surface_text: In view of certain matters about to be stated, the question of law as propounded by the High Court does number require to be companysidered. Kari Veerappa was the last male owner of the estate mentioned in his will, Exbt. P-2 a , which he executed on October 10, 1920.

facts.text: Kari Veerappa executed will Exbt. P-2 a on October 10, 1920

anchor.surface_text: Kari Veerappa was the last male owner of the estate mentioned in his will, Exbt. P-2 a , which he executed on October 10, 1920. Under this will he authorised his wife Setra Veeravva, first defendant, to adopt a son for the purpose of companytinuation of his family as he had numberissue.

facts.text: Kari Veerappa authorised his wife Setra Veeravva first defendant to adopt a son

anchor.surface_text: Under this will he authorised his wife Setra Veeravva, first defendant, to adopt a son for the purpose of companytinuation of his family as he had numberissue. The authority to adopt was in the following terms I have given her permission to adopt as many times as would be necessary, should the previous adoption be unsuccessful.

facts.text: Kari Veerappa died on October 23, 1920

anchor.surface_text: This gentle. man died on October 23, 1920. After his death, his widow made two attempts to adopt a son in accordance with his will.

facts.text: Veeravva made first attempt to adopt in 1939, boy died

anchor.surface_text: After his death, his widow made two attempts to adopt a son in accordance with his will. The first attempt was in 1939 which did number accomplish the purpose of the will as the person alleged to have been adopted died. The validity of this adoption was being questioned, but as the boy said to have been adopted had died, effects to dispute the adoption did number materialise.

facts.text: Veeravva adopted second defendant Sesalvada Kotra Basayya on October 11, 1942

anchor.surface_text: Veeravva thereafter, on October 11, 1942, adopted second defendant, Sesalvada Kotra Basayya. Two documents in this companynection are on the record.

facts.text: Registered agreement to adopt second defendant Exbt. D-25 dated September 18, 1942

anchor.surface_text: The first document is Exbt. D-25 dated the 18th of September, 1942, which was a registered agreement to adopt the second defendant. The second document is also a registered document, which is described as the deed of adoption and is dated June 23, 1943.

facts.text: Deed of adoption dated June 23, 1943 stating adoption on October 11, 1942

anchor.surface_text: The second document is also a registered document, which is described as the deed of adoption and is dated June 23, 1943. This clearly states that on October 11, 1942, Veeravva had adopted the 2nd defendant. Reference was also made in this document to the agreement of September 18, 1942.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit for declaration that adoption of second defendant invalid

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claiming to be the nearest reversioner of Kari Veerappa filed the present suit asking for a declaration that the adoption of the second defendant by Veeravva was invalid and number binding on the appellant or the other reversioners to the estate of the late Kari Veerappa. The suit filed by the appellant was heard by the District Judge of Bellary who dismissed it.

facts.text: District Judge of Bellary dismissed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The suit filed by the appellant was heard by the District Judge of Bellary who dismissed it. The appellant- appealed to the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed appeal and affirmed District Judge decision substantially

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- appealed to the High Court of Madras. His appeal was dismissed and the decision of the District Judge was substantially affirmed. The High Court did number allow companypensatory companyts granted by the District Judge, number did it agree with his finding that the appellant had failed to prove the relationship he had propounded and that lie was -not a reversioner at all,

facts.text: High Court found appellant is a reversioner but not proved nearest

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the High Court, the appellant was a relative and a reversioner, though he had number proved that he was the nearest reversioner alive at the time the appeal was heard and that he need number prove this until he actually sought to recover possession of the property after Veeravvas death.

facts.text: Hindu Succession Act 1956 came into force on June 17, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Since the Act came into force on June 17, 1956, and the decision of the High Court was given on March 25, 1955,

facts.text: Respondents raised preliminary objection that suit fails due to s.14 Hindu Succession Act 1956

anchor.surface_text: When this appeal came on for hearing the learned Advocate for the respondents took a preliminary objection that the suit filed by the plaintiff must in any event fail, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956  30 of 1956 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Agreement Exbt D-25 stated Veeravva to remain in possession during lifetime despite adoption

anchor.surface_text: But even on the adoption of the second defendant, the agreement to adopt dated September 18, 1942, stated that Veeravva was to remain in possession of her husbands estate during her life time in spite of the adoption.

facts.text: Written statement by Veeravva and second defendant stated she was in possession up to date

anchor.surface_text: In the written statement filed by Veeravva and the second defendant it was clearly stated in para. 6 thereof that Veeravva came into possession of her husbands property and that she recovered possession of the property companyered by the decree in 0. S. 20 of 1921 on the file of the Subordinate Judges Court, Bellary, and that she had been in sole possession of the said property up-to- date

facts.text: Second defendant affidavit admits Veeravva in possession per agreement 1942

anchor.surface_text: and that although she had adopted the second defendant on October 11, 1942, it was subject to retention of the enjoyment, possession and management by her of her husbands property during her life time. An affidavit had been filed in this Court by the second defendant in which he has clearly admitted that Veeravva is still in possession of his adoptive fathers estate in pursuance of the agreement of September 18, 1942.

facts.text: Court holds Veeravva in constructive possession through second defendant if adoption invalid

anchor.surface_text: In the present case if the adoption was invalid, the full owner of Veerappas estate was his widow Veeravva and even if it be assumed that the second defendant was in actual possession of the estate his possession was merely permissive and Veeravva must be regarded as being in companystructive possession of it through the second defendant.

facts.text: Suit not maintainable due to s.14 Hindu Succession Act even assuming invalid adoption

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, under the Act Veeravva becoming a full owner of her husbands estate, the suit companyld number succeed and the appeal must accordingly fail. In our opinion, the appellants suit was number maintainable, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Act, even if it be assumed that there was numbervalid adoption of the second defendant.

the learned Advocate for the respondents took a preliminary objection that the suit filed by the plaintiff must in any event fail, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956  30 of 1956 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Converts limited estate of female Hindu into full ownership if possessed at commencement of Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Act states- 14 1  Any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the companymencement of this Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and number as a limited owner.  1  1940 F.C.R. 84. Explanation.-In this sub-section, property includes both movable and immovable property acquired by a female Hindu by inheritance or devise, or at a partition, or in lieu of maintenance or arrears of maintenance, or by gift from any person, whether a relative or number, before, at or after her marriage, or by her own skill or exertion, or by purchase or by prescription, or in any other manner whatsoever, and also any such property held by her as stridhana immediately before the companymencement of this Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Full text of Section 14(1) and Explanation

anchor.surface_text: Nothing companytained in sub-section  1  shall apply to any property acquired by way of gift or under a will or any other instrument or under a decree or order of a civil companyrt or under an award where the terms of the gift, will or other instrument or the decree, order or award prescribe a restricted estate in such property.

concepts.interpretation: Does not apply where terms of will or instrument prescribe restricted estate; court finds no such prescription in will or agreement Exbt. D-25

issues.text: Whether the provisions of sub-section (2) of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act apply to the property due to restricted estate prescribed by the will Exbt. P-2 a or the agreement Exbt. D-25?

anchor.surface_text: Nothing contained in sub-section  1  shall apply to any property acquired by way of gift or under a will or any other instrument or under a decree or order of a civil court or under an award where the terms of the gift, will or other instrument or the decree, order or award prescribe a restricted estate in such property.

issues.text: Whether a reversioner can maintain a suit during the lifetime of a female Hindu to challenge an invalid adoption after she becomes a full owner under s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act?

anchor.surface_text: The act of Veeravva in the present case was to bring in a stranger. The appellant as a rever- sioner was, therefore, entitled during the life time of Veeravva to bring the present suit to obtain a declaration that the adoption of the second defendant was invalid.

issues.text: What is the essential question for consideration as to how the words 'any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of this Act' in s. 14 of the Act should be interpreted?

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the essential question for consideration is as to how the words any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether aquired before or after the commencement of this Act in s. 14 of the Act should be interpreted.

arguments.claim: Adoption invalid due to lack of approval/consent of five trustees in para14 will Exbt P-2a; authority ends if one refuses/dies/not accepts

anchor.surface_text: Is the adoption of the second defendant invalid, as the approval or consent of the five trustees mentioned in paragraph 14 of the will of Kari Veerappa, Exbt. P-2 a  was not obtained and is the authority to adopt at an end if any one of those five persons did not accept the trusteeship or died before the adoption or refused to give their approval .

arguments.court_reasoning: Question does not require consideration due to s.14

arguments.claim: Appellate court entitled to consider change in law post lower court decision

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that an appellate court is entitled to take into consideration any change in the law  vide the case of Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Keshwar Lal Chaudhuri 1 .

arguments.claim: 'Possessed' in s.14(1) in broad sense: state of owning/having in power, includes constructive possession, possession through agent/lessee etc.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view expressed above is the correct view as to how the words any property possessed by a female Hindu should be interpreted. In the present case if the adoption was invalid, the full owner of Veerappas estate was his widow Veeravva and even if it be assumed that the second defendant was in actual possession of the estate his possession was merely permissive and Veeravva must be regarded as being in constructive possession of it through the second defendant.

arguments.claim: s.14(2) not apply: will Exbt P-2a paras 1,4,12 do not prescribe restricted estate; agreement D-25 confers no estate on Veeravva

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that according to the will of Veerappa, Exbt. P2 a , in the properties mentioned in para. 1-of that will, Veeravva got only a restricted estate. The provisions of para. 4 of the will, however, make it clear that they would come into force only if the trustees mentioned in the will and Veeravva should disagree.

arguments.claim: Reversioner suit under s.42 Specific Relief Act illus f only preserves limited owner's estate, not applicable to full owner under s.14

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act, Illustration  f . In our opinion, this is of no avail to the appellant, because Illustration  f  obviously refers to a Hindu widows estate and has no reference to a full owner.

holdings.text: The question of law as propounded by the High Court regarding the validity of the adoption does not require to be considered.

anchor.surface_text: In view of certain matters about to be stated, the question of law as propounded by the High Court does not require to be considered. Kari Veerappa was the last male owner of the estate mentioned in his will, Exbt. P-2 a , which

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to preliminary objection under s.14 HSA rendering the adoption question moot as suit fails regardless.

holdings.text: The suit is not maintainable having regard to s.14 of the Hindu Succession Act even assuming no valid adoption of the second defendant, as Veeravva became full owner of her husband's estate.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, under the Act Veeravva becoming a full owner of her husbands estate, the suit could not succeed and the appeal must accordingly fail. In our opinion, the appellants suit was not maintainable,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Veeravva possessed the estate at commencement of Act; enlarged to full ownership; reversioner suit fails against full owner.

holdings.text: The words 'any property possessed by a female Hindu' in s.14 HSA refer to possession in a broad sense including constructive possession or possession in law, not merely actual physical possession.

anchor.surface_text: It was strongly urged on behalf of the appellant that the words any property possessed by a female Hindu in s. 14 of the Act referred to actual possession of the property whether the property was acquired

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Andhra Pradesh, Calcutta, Madhya Pradesh High Courts; possession includes through agent, lessee, permissive possession; cites dictionary meaning and context.

holdings.text: Veeravva was in possession of her husband's estate for purposes of s.14(1) HSA at the time the Act came into force, including constructive possession through the second defendant even if adoption invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case if the adoption was invalid, the full owner of Veerappas estate was his widow Veeravva and even if it be assumed that the second defendant was in actual possession of the estate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second defendant's possession permissive per agreement D-25; Veeravva full owner if no adoption, thus constructive possession.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.14(2) HSA do not apply as neither the will Exbt. P-2a nor agreement Exbt. D-25 prescribe a restricted estate in the property.

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that according to the will of Veerappa, Exbt. P2 a , in the properties mentioned in para. 1-of that will, Veeravva got only a restricted estate. The provisions of para. 4 of the will,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will paras 4 and 12 do not impose restriction unconditionally; agreement confers no estate, only possession during lifetime.

holdings.text: A reversioner cannot maintain a suit during the lifetime of a female Hindu who has become full owner under s.14 HSA to challenge an invalid adoption; s.42 Specific Relief Act illus. (f) applies only to limited estates.

anchor.surface_text: The act of Veeravva in the present case was to bring in a stranger. The appellant as a reversioner was, therefore, entitled during the life time of Veeravva to bring the present suit to obtain a declaration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reversioner's right preserves limited owner's estate; no such right against full owner; illus. (f) specific to Hindu widow's estate.

holdings.text: The words 'any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of this Act' in s.14 HSA should be interpreted to include constructive possession.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the essential question for consideration is as to how the words any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether aquired before or after the commencement of this Act in s. 14

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective for pre-Act acquisition if possessed at commencement; broad meaning to effectuate enlargement of limited estates.

anchor.surface_text: and in the case of Mt. Janki Kuer v. Chhathu Prasad 2  the Patna High Court took the view that the effect of ss. 14 and 15 of the Act was that a reversioner recognised as such under the Hindu law was numbermore a reversioner, as a female Hindu possessing any property, whether acquired before or after the companymencement of the Act, held number a limited estate but an absolute estate therein, and after the companying into force of the Act, he had numberright of reversion or any kind Of Spes successionsis. The High Courts of Calcutta, Andhra Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh have taken a view which does number support the view expressed by the Patna High Court in the aforesaid cases,

precedents.case_name: Mt. Janki Kuer v. Chhathu Prasad
precedents.cited_proposition: effect of ss. 14 and 15 of the Act was that a reversioner recognised as such under the Hindu law was numbermore a reversioner, as a female Hindu possessing any property held absolute estate

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh in the case of Mt. Lukai v. Niranjan 3  dissented from the decisions of the Patna High Court in the above-mentioned cases. Indeed, the Patna High Court in the case of A.I.R. 1957 Pat. 480.  2  A.I.R. 1957 Pat. 674. A.I.R. 1058 Madh. Pra. 160.

precedents.cited_proposition: dissented from the decisions of the Patna High Court

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the Patna High Court in the case of Harak Singh v. KailaSh Singh 1  overruled its previous decisions referred to above, and rightly pointed out that the object of the Act was to improve the legal status of Hindu women, enlarging their limited interest in property inherited or held by them to an absolute interest, provided they were in possession of the property when the Act came into force and, therefore, in a position to take advantage of its beneficial provisions but the Act was number intended to benefit alienees who with their eyes open purchased the property from the limited owners without justifying necessity before the Act came into force and at a time when the vendors had only a limited interest of Hindu women.

precedents.cited_proposition: overruled previous Patna decisions on ss.14-15; Act enlarges limited estate to absolute if in possession, not for alienees
precedents.cited_holding: the object of the Act was to improve the legal status of Hindu women... but the Act was number intended to benefit alienees...

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Gaddam Venkayamma v. Gaddam Veerayya 1  Viswanatha Sastri, J., with whom Satyanarayana Raju, J., agreed, expressed the opinion that the word possessed in s. 14 refers to possession on the date when the Act came into force. companyrse, possession referred to in s. 14 need number be actual physical possession or personal occupation of the property by the Hindu female-but may be possession in law. The possession of a licensee, lessee or a mortgagee from the female owner or the possession of a guardian or a trustee or an agent of the female owner would be her possession for the purpose of s. 14.

precedents.cited_proposition: word possessed in s. 14 refers to possession on the date when the Act came into force; includes possession in law, constructive possession, broad sense including ownership or control
precedents.cited_holding: The word possessed is used in s. 14 in a broad sense and in the companytext possession means the state of owning or having in ones hands or power. it includes possession by receipt of rents and profits.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Gostha Behari v. Haridas Samanta 2 , P. N. Mookherjee, J., expressed his opinion as to the meaning of the words any property possessed by a female Hindu in the following words- The opening words in property possessed by a female Hindu obviously mean that to companye within the purview of the section the property must be in possession of the female companycerned at the date of the companymencement of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: any property possessed by a female Hindu means property in her possession (actual, constructive or in any form recognised by law) at the date of commencement of the Act
precedents.cited_holding: That possession might have been either actual or companystructive or in any form recognised by law, but unless the female Hindu... was at least in such possession... the section would number apply.
